subject: Re: [junit] Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... Never, ever, ever? I can see why the System.out.println() is redundant here, since the assertEquals will provide the actual length of the vector on
messageBody:
> {
> System.out.println("value of langvect.length" +
> LanguageVector.length);
> assertEquals(2, LanguageVector.length);
> assertEquals("TOMCAT", LanguageVector.list.elementAt(0));
> assertEquals("EJB", LanguageVector.list.elementAt(1));
> assertEquals("COBOL", LanguageVector.list.elementAt(2));
> }


On Tue, 2003-09-16 at 19:33, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Simple refactoring #4: Never, ever, ever use System.out.println() in a
> test. Make an assertion instead.

Never, ever, ever? I can see why the System.out.println() is
redundant here, since the assertEquals will provide the actual
length of the vector on failure. But generally, when and where
are diagnostic messages in tests appropriate? Do you have a problem
with System.out.println() or diagnostic messages in tests in general?
